passages.text: Australia | Autos & Auto Parts Eagers

We can't deny it. In the prosaic world of Auto Dealers, this is one unique company. It controls \(14\%\) of Aust new vehicle sales (biggest US dealer \(2\%\) ), it owns Aust's leading Used offering with metrics that would make Carvana blush. Its scale offers OEM entrants instant national access. Its RE drives ongoing operational flexibility. 1H25 was part beat (rev, EBITDA)/part miss (NPAT) but outlook was positive. We've adj. FY25- 27 EPS \(\sim +6\%\) . New PT A\(18\) (A\(15.50)

- 1H25 Revenue A\(6,497m, + 19\% pcp (+8\% / + 7\% \text{beat vs JEF/Street})\)- 1H25 Gross profit A\(1,083m, + 11\% pcp (+4\% / + 2\% \text{beat vs JEF/Street})\)- 1H25 GP margin 16.7\%, -110bps pcp (-50bps/-80bps miss vs JEF/Street)- 1H25 Group U-EBITDA post AASB16 A\(367m, + 11\% pcp (+4\% / + 6\% \text{beat vs JEF/Street})\)- 1H25 Group U-PBT post AASB16 A\(194m, + 9\% pcp (+3\% \text{beat vs JEF/Street})\)- 1H25 NPAT post-mins A\(119m, + 6\% pcp (-3\% \text{miss vs JEF/Street})\)- 1H25 DPS 24c, unchanged pcp (-4c/-5c miss vs JEF/Street)

Outlook: "APE expects to see the following evidenced in FY25 results: Further revenue growth supported by improving market conditions; Improved contributions from ongoing integration/ optimisation of recent large- scale acquisitions; Continued growth in asayauto123; Ongoing disciplined cost management; Unlocking further organic and M&A growth."

Forecast Changes: With the big revenue beat (largely BYD driven), we've increased FY25- 27 Revenue \(\sim 8\%\) and we've trimmed FY25- 27 GP margin \(\sim 50bp\) (due to ongoing neg. mix shift to BYD). Net outcome is FY25- 27 EPS \(+5\% , + 6\% , + 7\%\) .
Figure 1 - APE Forecast Changes
Source: Jefferies 0rmates

JEF Comment: It's standard fare for tech analysts to struggle with valuation metrics but not traditional industrial analysts. There is so much to like about APE with its dominant market position, its scale driving cost efficiencies, its burgeoning unique relationships (BYD, Subsubhi) and its unique growth businesses (easyauto123). But its valuation metrics post today's short squeeze just look too high. The market appears to be pricing in deals yet to happen. We can't get there.
Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-US analysts on pages 9 - 16 of this report. \* Jefferies (Australia) Pty Ltd

Figure 2 - Aust New Vehicle Sales - Rolling 12 Months

APE is a well- managed company with scale advantages and a successful track record of value creation. It has a solid ability to continue to consolidate the market (though less than pre- AHG M&A). Additionally, with the rise of EVs, APE looks well- positioned to capitalise given their exclusive agreement with BYD.

On the negative front, FY23 was cycle peak for auto dealers and margins are now under pressure. Demand appears to be weakening as supply is freeing up. As supply continues to open up, this will lead to ongoing lower margins. We like APE but see it as fairly priced in the context of the weakening cycle.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

We value APE on a DCF basis (comp multiple basis is problematic given APE's unique opportunity set). Our DCF assumes GP margins remain at \(16.7\%\) and includes A\\$300m surplus property valuation (above BV).
Our upside scenario assumes \(5\%\) higher sales growth to FY27 and that GP margins normalise to \(18\%\) and includes A\\$300m surplus property valuation (above BV).
Our downside scenario assumes \(- 5\%\) lower sales growth to FY27 and that GP margins normalise to \(16.8\%\) . No surplus property included in DCF.
The changeover from ICE vehicles to EVs over the next twenty years remains the key negative / threat to APE.
1) No targets for reducing its greenhouse gas emissions.
2) Sustainability targets have not been set by the company.

1) The automotive sector is transitioning from Internal Combustion Engines (ICE) to Electric Vehicles (EV). This change, though likely to be gradually phased in over ten years or more, will be profound. What are the key commercial implications for the company from this transition?

2) Though the company has made efforts towards addressing gender imbalance, less than \(10\%\) of management positions are held by females, females comprise \(22\%\) of the board, and just \(25\%\) of non- management roles are held by females. What steps have been taken to address and improve this gender imbalance?
3) The company set carbon emissions targets and what steps have been taken to reduce emissions going forward?
- Further meaningful M&A- Successful completion of the Brisbane auto mall project

- Declining Australian household disposable income and median house prices impacting auto demand- Any government policy supporting a more rapid roll-out of EVs and the phasing out of ICE vehicles- Sell-down by major shareholder Nick Politis- More OEMs moving from a franchise to an agency model- Loss of the BYD exclusive distribution arrangement

The big surprise from the result was revenue \((8\%)\) (at) with most of this coming from BYD's explosive sales. The company had guided for 11b incremental revenue in FY25, and they achieved this in 1H25. GP margins were actually \(\sim 50\) bps under JEF. This was due to negative mix shift to BYD (inherent lower margins given no Service, Parts or Used at this point) and easyauto123 (again, Used car margins are \(\sim 10\%\) vs APE Group margins \(\sim 17\%\) ). Higher Net financing costs and Minorities drove a \(\sim 2\%\) NPAT miss.
Figure 3-APE 1H25 Result Variance-P&L

APE doesn't generally talk about OEMs in its presentations and consistent with this policy, there was very little mention of BYD. However, it's clear that the \(8\%\) revenue beat was largely due to BYD's explosive sales growth. BYD started CY25 at \(\sim 2\%\) of Aust New Vehicle unit sales. By Jun- 25, that had grown to \(6\%\) . We understand BYD is targeting medium- term unit sales of \(100k\) , which would comprise \(\sim 10\%\) of Aust New Vehicle unit sales. Beyond that, we understand they are aiming at Toyota levels of share (200k vehicles pa or \(\sim 20\%\) share).
Figure 5-BYD Contribution to APE

A key unknown is how much sales leakage will occur (from APE to other dealers) now that the distribution agreement is non- exclusive. We suspect APE's infrastructure/prime auto real estate will mitigate any material leakage over our forecast period to FY27 but beyond that, this remains a risk.
Figure 6 - BYD Unit Sales - Monthly
Figure 7 - BEV + PHEV Share of New Vehicles Sold in Australia

APE inherited the easyauto123 Used vehicle business in its acquisition of Automotive Holdings (ticker AHG) in 2019. Prior to that, APE had been pursuing its own unique Used model but post acquisition, it concentrated its efforts in easyauto123.

Today, easyauto123 is by far, the dominant national specialty Used car retailer. It sources the bulk of its inventory from the APE dealer network (trade- ins) which gives it a significant advantage over any other participant which has to source vehicles from car auctions.
In spite of being the largest player by a significant margin, it still represents a tiny share of the \(\sim 3m\) used vehicles that are bought and sold each year.

Profitability has been ramping up strongly in recent years as high fixed costs (retail outlets, service/repair centres etc) are amortised over strongly growing unit sales volumes. This curve will eventually level out but we see more upside over the next few years.
Figure 8 - easyauto123 - Net Operating Profit/Unit
Source: Company, Jefferies

APE has an extensive strata- owned real estate portfolio, as well as significant leasehold properties with varying expiry profiles. The company continues to dynamically manage this estate to maximise sales efficiency and generate gains on sale on properties that are no longer needed in the operating business. The ratios were impacted throughout Covid but Fig. 9 indicates that APE is getting more sales from its real estate over time. We think this will accelerate over the next five years.
Figure 9 - APE Real Estate (Strata & Leasehold) Sales Efficiency

With the big revenue beat (largely BYD driven), we've increased FY25- 27 Revenue \(\sim 8\%\) and we've trimmed FY25- 27 GP margin \(\sim 50bp\) (due to ongoing neg. mix shift to BYD). Net outcome is FY25- 27 EPS \(+5\%\) \(+6\%\) \(+7\%\)
Figure 10-APE Forecast Changes

We value APE solely on a DCF basis (comp multiple basis is problematic given APE's unique opportunity set). Our DCF assumes GP margins remain at \(16.7\%\) (1H25 level), and includes A\$300m surplus property valuation (above BV). On this basis, our valuation is A\$17.86 and our PT is A\$18.
On our new forecasts and post APE's strong price move today, APE trades on well over 2x the FY25 PE multiples of our US comp set (26x vs US comp set average 11x).

EagersEagers Automotive Ltd. engages in the management of automotive dealerships. Its activities include the sale of new and used vehicles; distribution and sale of parts, and accessories; repair and servicing of vehicles; provision of extended warranties, facilitation of finance and leasing in respect of motor vehicles; and the ownership of property and investments. The company has grown significantly over the past twenty years via acquisition and it now has around \(12\%\) share of all new motor vehicle retailing in Australia. Eagers operates through the following segments: Car Retailing, Truck Retailing, Property, and Investment. The Car Retailing segment offers a range of automotive products and services, including new, used, maintenance and repair services, parts, extended service contracts, brokerage, and protection for vehicles. The Truck Retailing segment provides products and services, including new trucks, used trucks, truck maintenance and repair services, truck parts, extended service contracts, truck protection products, and other aftermarket products. The Property segment includes the acquisition and ownership of commercial properties use as facility premises for its motor dealership operations. The company was founded by Edward Eager and Frederick Eager on January 7, 1913 and is headquartered in Brisbane, Australia.
We utilise one valuation methodology to arrive at our PT - DCF.

We have identified 5 key risks to investing in APE: 1) The cycle - Though new car volumes are still below peak 2017 levels, gross margins on selling new and used cars are high and potentially at record levels. We see downside in margins though as supply opens up. The interplay of these two factors will be a key driver of medium- term earnings; 2) House prices - Australian house prices have enjoyed a boom during Covid driven by global stimulus and ultra- low rates. A significant reversal in median house prices (the negative wealth effect) would be highly detrimental to demand for new vehicles. This remains a key risk on exiting covid; 3) Disruptive business models - These would include ride- sharing / short- term rental business models; direct- to- retail customer business models; and online business models impacting volumes sold and serviced by traditional auto retailers; 4) Shift to EVs away from ICE vehicles being accelerated by government policy; and 5) Change to certain OEM traditional channels to market with a move from a franchise model to an agency model, which has created some uncertainty.

In terms of upside risk to our valuation, if new vehicle supply remains constrained into the medium term under a changed manufacturing / distribution approach of the major OEMs (less production, better margin per vehicle), then it is feasible that auto dealer margins remain elevated into the medium term.
BYD Co LtdA/H PT of Rmb447/HK\$450 based on 24x 2025E PE, 1x PEG. Risks include: 1) weaker-than- expected NEV sales in FY25, 2) margin erosion given tougher competition in NEV segment.
BYD Co LtdA/H PT of Rmb447/HK\$159 based on 24x 2025E PE, 1x PEG. Risks include: 1) weaker-than- expected NEV sales in FY25, 2) margin erosion given tougher competition in NEV segment.

CarvanaOur PT is based on a DCF, which we justify using a peer analysis of the implied forward EV/Revenue multiple. Upside risks. (1) Revenue growth accelerates back to prior levels, (2) Retail GPU expands to reach KMX's level faster than expected, (3) Restructuring changes to the monetization of finance receivables causes a permanent uplift in Other GPU, (4) Increased Revenue and SG&A reductions drive OPEX leverage and EBITDA margins toward long- term targets. Downside risks: (1) Retail Units decelerate, (2) Margins decelerate, (3) Difficulty acquiring inventory at attractive economics, (4) Disruption in ABS market

Toyota MotorOur ¥2,300 price target is based on 9.5x FY3/24E P/E, a 25% premium to the sector average. Risks include more yen appreciation than expected, weakening of emerging economies, and weak assessment of the successor executive team.

Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed
Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period.

Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio

and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop.
